Please explain why lint is disabled here.

I disabled this line because the function's currently unused, since we don't support updating fabric networks. I can just remove this functions and the commented out lines below on 184-186, though, and we can add back whatever we need if we ever add support.
Yes. We should do this more.
Is it safe to reference oparams here rather than params, which has been validated?

It's safe, but for a bit of a roundabout way that I figured out while doing the validation changes:

- If someone sends something to /networks/<uuid>/ips that's valid JSON but not an object, and it's falsey, then restify replaces it with an object.
- If someone sends something to /networks/<uuid>/ips that's valid JSON but not an object, and it's truthy, then restify will silently fail to save "network_uuid" to the object, and then the handler that expects it to be there will fail to find it and return an error.
- If someone does send an object, then anything in the "network_uuid" field will be overwritten by restify with the <uuid> component of the path, and anything in the "network" field will be overwritten by the handler that expects "network_uuid" in order to construct the Network object.

So by the time we get here, we know that oparams is an object and has valid "network_uuid" and "network" fields.
Would prefer to have unified callback/return conventions, at least within the function.
Agreed. I've reworked this function.
Please explain why lint is disabled.

This line's disabled since nothing refers to "NAPI". h.createNAPIclient() needs to be called though to initialize the client for the helper library functions used throughout this test suite, though. I can modify this line to dump the "var NAPI =" bit and keep it just for the side effect. I kept the "var NAPI =" bit mostly for uniformity with other files.

It reads here that if we have a callback, we will never call t.end(), which can prevent tests from continuing; is there a reasonable way to call the callback and t.end()?

Also (thanks Gerrit) I can't see where we'd call this with a callback - could use an explanation for this change. :)

This is for the change I made in test/integration/network-owner.test.js, which brings the behaviour of deleteNicTags to be more in line with how most of the other helpers in this file work: if a test function takes a callback, it'll call it when finished, so that the caller can continue doing other checks. Otherwise, it'll end the test for you. I'm not crazy about the pattern, but it's how all the other delete* helpers work.
Mistaken strict here?
